text: for this recipe I pair the brisket with
a gremolata and instead of using garlic
usually gremolata is garlic parsley and
lemon I'm using horseradish when you're
buying brisket you're gonna have two
options first cut which is very lean or
second cut which is fattier go for the
second cut it's gonna give you juicier
meat always season your meat ahead if
you can do it the day before garlic salt
and pepper some time or other herbs
whatever you like you want to just brush
all this off the meat before the meat
hits the pan take a minute and get your
pan nice and hot so that when you add
the oil to the pan it's gonna thin
immediately and then when you add the
brisket you're gonna get that audible
sear there are some recipes that don't
have you Syria brisket and those recipes
rely on some sort of canned soup or
onion soup mix or something like that
since you're not allowing the flavor to
build naturally from searing the meat
the darker your sear the more intense
your Fond is going to be the Fond is
those brown bits on the bottom of the
pan and your Fond is the basis of the
sauce
don't worry so much about deglazing once
you add your vegetables they're gonna
deglaze for you and especially when you
pour the wine in it all comes up by
itself I like to cook my brisket in the
oven because you get a nice even heat
and it's gonna cook it slowly and gently
and that just gives you the best texture
the gremolata is usually parsley lemon
zest and garlic in my recipe I use
horseradish instead of garlic it gives
the same bite but a different flavor I'm
using a large kind of a cheese grater
for this because I want it to look this
size I want it to be bigger than a
really fine microplane anytime you have
richness and you want to contrast it
with brightness a little gremolata is
going to fix it and then together you're
getting a very complex and delicious
dish
Oh
Oh
